overview: The purpose of this measure is to establish a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the Second and Fifth Circuits. [6] The program is intended to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs. [6] The measure also requires the Third Circuit of the Judiciary and Big Island Drug Court to conduct an interim study to establish a blueprint for a women's court pilot program in the Third Circuit. [6] This measure sunsets on 6/30/2028. [5]

assumptions_and_methodology: The Department of Health's request for a budget of $801,802 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-25-25_.PDF.txt) is based on the Department’s staffing requirements for the operation of the existing Women’s Court pilot project of the First Circuit. [5] The Judiciary's proposal for the Third Circuit calls for situating a Big Island Women's Court under the supervision of the Big Island Drug Court to leverage existing structure and staff. [5]
agency_impact: This bill would establish a three-year women’s court pilot program in the second and fifth circuits. [5] It also requires the third circuit of the Judiciary and Big Island Drug Court to conduct an interim study. [5] [5] The Judiciary, however, proposes modifications to the bill, including a request that the Second and Fifth Circuits be deleted from consideration for the pilot project, offering instead to pilot a modified model in the Third Circuit. [5] [5] In 2024, for the existing First Circuit program, the Department of Health conducted 33 mental health screenings and 24 psychological assessments of participants. [5] [5]
economic_impact: The goal of the project is diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. [5] Expansion to the other circuits would allow the program to assist more women in need and divert them away from incarceration. [5] The program is intended to ensure that justice-involved women are given an opportunity to rebuild their lives, contributing positively to society rather than being trapped in cycles of crime and incarceration. [5]
